head.title: Are Colder Days Ahead for Wall Street?

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Banking, Finance and Insurance

hedline.hl1: Are Colder Days Ahead for Wall Street?

abstract.p: Databank column on post-Labor Day cooling of technology stocks; graphs (M)

block.p: First they sizzled, then they fizzled.
Technology shares turned cool in post-Labor Day trading, as investors, reacting to a series of earnings warnings, chose to take profits after the market's hot August rally.
First they sizzled, then they fizzled.
Technology shares turned cool in post-Labor Day trading, as investors, reacting to a series of earnings warnings, chose to take profits after the market's hot August rally.

Several analysts also issued downgrades of prominent technology companies, including Intel, WorldCom and Micron Technology, citing concern that weak demand could result in lower-than-expected revenue growth in the coming months.
There's some concern about a slowing of the economy, after the Federal Reserve's interest rate increases over the past year, said Barry Berman, head trader for Robert W. Baird & Company.
The profit-taking was not out of line, he added. We had some big run-ups.

The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index, which climbed nearly 12 percent last month, ended the week at 3,979.32, down 255.92, while the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 11,221.76, down 18.13.
Mr. Berman predicted that trading would remain volatile this week. We're looking at the end-of-the-quarter portfolio adjustments and earnings pre-announcements.
